questions.text: In the procedure indicated by the image below, what is the storage medium and suture used?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The donor corneal graft is stored in McCarey–Kaufman (MK) medium, and the graft is typically secured to the host cornea using 10-0 nylon sutures.

McCarey-Kaufman medium has a pink appearance and contains Tissue Culture-199, 5 % Dextran-40, HEPES buffer to maintain a pH of 7.4, and gentamicin (0.1 mg/mL). Corneal tissue can be transplanted directly after retrieval or preserved in an eye bank for varying durations, depending on the method:

  • Short-term storage (24-96 hours): moist chamber or MK medium
  • Intermediate storage (up to about 2 weeks): medium enriched with chondroitin sulfate
  • Long-term storage (months to years): cryopreservation in liquid nitrogen or storage in glycerol, which can maintain viability for roughly a year

Corneal transplantation (keratoplasty) involves replacing a diseased or opaque cornea with a clear donor cornea. The procedure includes:

  • Trephining and removing the donor corneal button
  • Removing the corresponding portion of the recipient cornea
  • Securing the donor graft to the recipient bed with either continuous or interrupted 10-0 nylon sutures.

Explanations for other Options:

McCarey-Kaufman medium & Vicryl suture(Option B): MK medium is correct for storage, but Vicryl (polyglactin 910) is an absorbable suture that loses tensile strength rapidly and causes more inflammation, making it unsuitable for delicate, long-term corneal wound closure.

Moist chamber & silk suture (Option C): A moist chamber can temporarily keep a whole eye viable for only a few hours and is not the standard for corneal graft storage.

Ethylene glycol & Vicryl suture (Option D): Ethylene glycol is an antifreeze compound, not a corneal preservation medium. Vicryl, as noted, is absorbable and inappropriate for corneal graft fixation.

questions.text: All the following are used in amblyopia therapy except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Management of amblyopia includes multiple therapeutic approaches, but strabismus surgery is not a primary treatment.

Surgical correction of squint is considered only after other amblyopia therapies have been completed and visual improvement has plateaued, making it the final step in management.

Early intervention is critical, ideally beginning before 3 years of age, for the best visual outcomes.

  • Treatment strategies include:
    • Optical correction: Appropriate spectacles or contact lenses are prescribed to correct refractive errors, especially in anisometropic amblyopia.
    • Occlusion therapy: Patching the better-seeing eye to stimulate visual use of the amblyopic eye is the cornerstone of therapy. Duration (full-time or part-time) depends on the child's age and the severity of amblyopia.
    • Penalisation: Intentional blurring of the sound eye-using atropine drops or over-plus lenses-serves as an alternative when patching is impractical.
    • Pharmacologic support: Agents such as levodopa/carbidopa may be used to enhance visual stimulation alongside patching.
    • Pleoptic training: Previously employed to restore foveal fixation in young children, but now less common.
    • Perceptual learning techniques: Engaging in video games or similar visual tasks can supplement patching to improve visual acuity.
    • Computer-based active vision therapy: Specialized software programs designed for home use apply the principle of operant conditioning and are frequently combined with occlusion therapy as an adjunct.

questions.text: The type of retinal detachment seen in uncontrolled diabetes is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Advanced diabetes mellitus can lead to tractional retinal detachment (TRD).

TRD occurs when fibrous membranes in the vitreous contract and pull the neurosensory retina away from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). In uncontrolled proliferative diabetic retinopathy, abnormal new vessels and fibrous tissue form on the retinal surface; as these membranes shrink, they exert traction and lift the retina.

Types of retinal detachment
Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina from the RPE and is classified into three major forms:

  • Rhegmatogenous (primary): caused by a full-thickness retinal break.
  • Tractional: due to mechanical pulling by vitreoretinal membranes.
  • Exudative (serous): from accumulation of subretinal fluid without a tear or traction.

Other causes of tractional detachment include:

  • Retinopathy of prematurity
  • Eales' disease
  • Sickle-cell retinopathy
  • Incontinentia pigmenti
  • Post-haemorrhagic retinitis proliferans
  • Ocular toxocariasis
  • Vitreomacular traction syndrome
  • Retinal dysplasia

Clinical features of TRD:
The detached retina typically shows a concave configuration, with markedly reduced mobility, and there are no retinal breaks or shifting subretinal fluid. Because the process is gradual, patients usually do not experience photopsia or floaters, which are common in rhegmatogenous detachments.

Explanations for other Options:

Rhegmatogenous (Option A): Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment develops when a full-thickness break-such as a retinal hole or tear-allows liquefied vitreous to leak beneath the sensory retina, separating it from the retinal pigment epithelium.

Exudative (Option C): Exudative (serous) retinal detachment results from the build-up of fluid under the retina, which lifts the neurosensory retina away from the pigment epithelium. This fluid accumulation is typically secondary to inflammatory disorders or vascular abnormalities.

choices.text: 70% of multiple sclerosis patients present with optic neuritis
Optic neuritis presents with a normal fundus with no disc edema
Oral steroid is used for treatment
Visual field and color defects are proportional to the disease

questions.text: Which of the following is true about optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fundus can appear normal without disc swelling, as seen in retrobulbar neuritis.

Types of optic neuritis:

  • Papillitis: Inflammation affects the optic disc itself, producing visible disc changes.
  • Neuroretinitis: Both the optic disc and adjacent macular retina are involved.
  • Retrobulbar neuritis: The optic nerve behind the globe is inflamed, so the optic disc looks normal, and there is no disc edema.

Explanations for other Options:

70% of multiple sclerosis patients present with optic neuritis (Option A): Optic neuritis is the initial presenting feature in only about 30 % of patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). Over the course of the disease, approximately 50 % of people with MS will experience at least one episode of optic neuritis

Oral steroid is used for treatment (Option C): High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone followed by a short oral taper is the recommended regimen when treatment is indicated.
Oral corticosteroids alone are specifically avoided because they do not speed visual recovery and increase the risk of recurrent optic neuritis.

Visual field and color defects are proportionate with disease (Option D): Loss of colour vision and contrast sensitivity often exceeds the decrease in visual acuity and does not necessarily correlate directly with the degree of visual field loss.

choices.text: Visual acuity <6/60 after correction in the better eye
Visual acuity <3/60 after correction in the better eye
Visual acuity <6/60 without correction in the better eye
Visual acuity <3/60 without correction in the better eye

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Blindness is defined as severe visual impairment in the better-seeing eye, even after best possible correction.
  • A person with visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye is considered blind, meaning they can see at 3 meters what a person with normal vision can see at 60 meters.

Explanations for other Options:

Visual acuity <6/60 after correction in better eye (Option A): This defines severe visual impairment, not blindness.

Visual acuity <6/60 without correction in better eye (Option C): vision should be measured after best correction to determine true blindness.

Visual acuity <3/60 without correction in better eye (Option D): vision should be measured after best correction to determine true blindness.

questions.text: Which is the best test to visualize all layers of the retina?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Optical coherence tomography (OCT) allows in vivo visualization of the individual retinal layers.

This non-invasive, non-contact imaging technique uses low-coherence light waves to create high-resolution cross-sectional (tomographic) scans of both the anterior and posterior segments of the eye. The resulting images resemble an "in-vivo histologic section" of the retina and are captured in the near-infrared spectrum.

In cases such as central serous retinopathy, OCT demonstrates a neurosensory retinal detachment from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium, providing detailed structural information crucial for diagnosis and monitoring.

An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below.

Explanations for other Options:

Perimetry (Option A): Perimetry measures the visual field, helping to detect and map any defects or areas of vision loss.

Fluorescence angiography (Option C): Fluorescein angiography visualises the retinal and choroidal vasculature by tracking the circulation of intravenously injected fluorescein dye, enabling assessment of vascular and structural abnormalities in a variety of fundus disorders.

Ultrasound B-Scan (Option D): B-scan ocular ultrasound is employed to evaluate the posterior segment of the eye when the view is obscured by opaque media. It is also valuable for identifying and localising intraocular or orbital tumours and other space-occupying lesions.

questions.text: Two weeks after cataract surgery, a patient presents with flare and cells in the anterior chamber (AC). What is the probable diagnosis and cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A patient presenting two weeks after cataract surgery with marked vision loss (visual acuity 5/60), anterior chamber cells, vitreous haze, and an obscured fundus is most likely suffering from postoperative endophthalmitis, commonly caused by Staphylococcus species.

Endophthalmitis refers to inflammation of the internal ocular structures-including the uvea and retina-with exudates in the vitreous, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber. Typical features include ocular pain, eyelid swelling, and severe visual decline.

Types and Etiology

  • Early-onset postoperative endophthalmitis
    • Appears within 4 weeks of surgery, often within the first week.
    • Usual pathogens: Staphylococcus epidermidis, Staphylococcus aureus, various Streptococcus species, and gram-negative organisms such as Pseudomonas, Proteus, Haemophilus influenzae, Klebsiella, Escherichia coli, Bacillus, and Enterobacter. Anaerobes may also be involved.
  • Delayed-onset postoperative endophthalmitis
    • Develops after 4 weeks.
    • Common organisms: Propionibacterium (Cutibacterium) acnes and fungi, including Aspergillus, Fusarium, Candida, Cephalosporium, and Penicillium.

Treatment:

The cornerstone of therapy is intravitreal antibiotics, administered after aspirating 0.2-0.3 mL of vitreous for smear and culture. Adjunctive measures can include topical antibiotics, cycloplegics, oral corticosteroids, and, in severe cases, pars plana vitrectomy.

Key takeaway:

Complications of cataract surgery

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis shown in the diagram is Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO).

In INO, the lesion occurs in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). In the example provided, during leftward gaze, the right eye shows impaired adduction while the left eye demonstrates nystagmus during abduction. This indicates a lesion in the right MLF, which disrupts coordinated eye movement during left gaze, whereas rightward gaze remains normal. Typically, INO is characterized by impaired adduction on the side of the lesion and abduction of nystagmus in the contralateral eye

Horizontal eye movements are initiated by the horizontal gaze center, or paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). The PPRF sends two main outputs:

  • To the ipsilateral sixth cranial nerve nucleus, producing abduction of the same-side eye.
  • The contralateral medial longitudinal fasciculus, which relays the signal to the opposite third cranial nerve nucleus, causes adduction of the contralateral eye.

These two pathways from the PPRF coordinate to generate conjugate horizontal eye movements.

Explanations for other Options:

3rd cranial nerve palsy (Option B): Third cranial nerve (oculomotor) palsy causes ptosis, and the eye is typically deviated downwards and outwards, with slight torsion, due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.

Horizontal gaze palsy (Option C): Horizontal gaze palsy results from a lesion in the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). This produces an inability to move both eyes toward the side of the lesion, causing ipsilateral horizontal gaze weakness.

Thyroid eye disease (Option D): Thyroid eye disease (Graves orbitopathy) presents with lid retraction, lid lag, and proptosis, reflecting the effects of autoimmune orbital tissue inflammation and fibrosis..
